title: Two shot in killed in Irvine
caption: Photo: Facebook
body: Monica Quan, 28, and her fiancé Keith Lawrence, 27, are found shot to death in their car at an Irvine parking structure. It's later revealed that Quan, an assistant women's basketball coach at Cal State-Fullerton, is the daughter of Randal Quan, a former LAPD captain who became a lawyer in retirement and represented Christopher Dormer in front of the Board of Rights, a tribunal that ruled against Dorner at the time of his dismissal. (KPCC & AP)

title: Dorner's belongings near San Diego
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: Some of Dorner 's belongings are found in a trash bin in the San Diego-area community of National City. (AP)

title: Dorner checks into San Diego naval base
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: Dorner checks into a base hotel at Naval Base Point Loma in San Diego and leaves the next day without checking out, Navy Cmdr. Brad Fagan says. (KPCC)

title: Dorner leaves Naval Base Point Loma
caption: Photo: Naval Base Point Loma website
body: Dorner leaves the base hotel at Naval Base Point Loma without checking out, according to Navy Cmdr. Fagan. (KPCC)

title: Dorner formally named as suspect in weekend homicides
caption: Photo: Facebook
body: Irvine police announce they are looking for Dorner as a suspect in the killings of Quan and Lawrence, and say he implicated himself in the killings in a manifesto posted on Facebook. The LAPD releases the manifesto allegedly written by Christopher Dorner that names Asian-American, lesbian and Hispanic police officers as “high value targets.” (KNBC & AP)

title: Man tries to steal a boat from San Diego marina
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: San Diego police say a man matching Dorner's description attempted to steal a 47-foot boat from the city's Shelter Island marina at around 10:30 p.m. When the engine failed to start, the suspect tied up an 81-year-old man who was on the boat and then fled. (AP & KPCC)

title: Man fires on officers near Corona
caption: Photo: Grant Slater/KPCC
body: About 1:30 a.m., two LAPD officers begin following a motorist believed to be Dorner on Interstate 15 in the Riverside County community of Corona. The motorist exits near Corona, leaves the truck and fires a shouldered weapon at the officers, who had been assigned to protect people authorities believe Dorner is targeting. One of the officers is injured. (KPCC, KTLA & AP)

title: Riverside officer shot and killed, another wounded
caption: Photo: Kevin Warn/AP
body: At 1:35 a.m. a man police believe is Dorner ambushes two police officers in Riverside at the corner of Magnolia and Arlington, killing a 34-year-old officer and severely wounding a 27-year-old officer. Police ask the media not to release the officers' names, to protect the families. (KPCC)

title: LAPD badge, Dorner's ID found near San Diego Intl Airport
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: About 2:30 a.m. San Diego police receive a wallet with a Los Angeles Police Department detective badge and a picture ID supposedly belonging to Christopher Dorner that a citizen found on a curb near San Diego International Airport. The citizen gave the wallet to a shuttle bus driver, who contacted police. (KPCC & KTLA)

title: Search extends to Las Vegas
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: The search for Dorner extends to the Las Vegas area. Clark County property records show Dorner owns a small two-story, three-bedroom home in a neighborhood about nine miles southwest of the Las Vegas Strip. Clark County property records show he bought the house in 2007 for about $265,000. (AP)

title: Officers shoot two who are are delivering newspapers in pickup truck
caption: Photo: Brian Watt/KPCC
body: About 5:15 a.m. two women delivering the L.A. Times are mistakenly shot by LAPD officers searching for Dorner in the 19500 block of Redbeam Avenue, Torrance police Lt. Devin Chase said. The women were in a Toyota Tundra pickup truck similar to Dorner's vehicle and taken to area hospitals. One victim had minor hand injuries. Another received a gunshot wound in the back. (L.A. Times & KPCC)

title: Officers mistakenly shoot at a second pickup truck
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: In a second officer-involved shooting, Torrance police shoot at a pickup truck near Flagler Lane and Beryl Street at about 5:45 a.m. No injuries are reported. (L.A. Times/AP)

title: Authorities find burned pickup near Big Bear
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: About 8:30 a.m. reports surface that authorities are investigating a burned pickup truck near the Big Bear ski area in the San Bernardino Mountains. A San Bernardino County sheriff's deputy says there have been no sightings of Dorner but local school officials decide to put schools in lockdown. (AP)

title: Arizona authorities alerted to search
body: About 9:30 a.m. authorities in central and northern Arizona are alerted about the manhunt for Dorner. (AP)

title: Naval Base Point Loma is locked down
caption: Photo: Point Loma website
body: About 9:40 a.m., Naval Base Point Loma in San Diego is locked down after a Navy worker reports seeing someone who resembles Dorner. Two hours later, Navy officials say they don't believe Dorner was on base. (AP)

title: "Multiple weapons at his disposal"
caption: Photo: Damian Dovarganes/AP
body: During a 10 a.m. news conference LAPD Police Chief Charlie Beck describes Dorner's vehicle as a late model Nissan Titan pickup, dark gray, 4-doors, roof rack, black rims and a Department of Defense sticker on the front windshield. Beck says Dorner has multiple weapons at his disposal, including an assault weapon. (KPCC)

title: False alarm in San Diego
caption: Photo: Denis Poroy/Getty Images
body: San Diego police respond to reports of a man seen in a hotel matching Dorner's description. The reports prove to be false. (KPCC)

title: Official confirms Dorner attended Norwalk Christian Academy
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: A Norwalk Christian School official says Dorner's second-grade portrait was in the school's 1987 yearbook. It was not clear if he was pictured in the yearbooks from other years. In his manifesto Dorner mentioned attending Norwalk Christian School, where he described striking a fellow first-grader who taunted him with a racial slur. Dorner described it as his "first recollection of racism." (Inland Valley Daily Bulletin)

title: Big Bear resident notices fire from Dorner's truck
caption: Photo: Grant Slater/KPCC
body: Randy Linville, a property manager of vacation homes in the upscale neighborhood at the base of the Bear Mountain ski resort, first noticed the fire from Dorner's truck about 11 a.m. above a golf course northwest of the ski resort. "At first, I thought it was a controlled burn," he told KPCC. "So I didn't pay a lot of attention. ... And then I got text messages from friends mentioning that they think he's in Big Bear."

title: Officials confirm burned truck is Dorner's
caption: Photo: Grant Slater/KPCC
body: Authorities confirm about 2:30 p.m. that the pickup truck found near Bear Mountain ski area at Big Bear Lake belongs to Dorner. (AP)

title: Door-to-door search starts in Big Bear
caption: Photo: Grant Slater/KPCC
body: During a 3:30 p.m. news conference San Bernardino County Sheriff John McMahon announces that a door-to-door search for Dorner is under way. (AP)

title: Agents search Dorner's Las Vegas home
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: About 4 p.m., FBI agents and local law enforcement officials serve a search warrant at a Las Vegas-area home belonging to Dorner. Authorities leave with boxes of items from the two-story house but decline to disclose what evidence has been found. (AP)

title: FAA orders helicopters out of airspace near search location
caption: Photo: Grant Slater/KPCC
body: About 5:11 p.m. The Federal Aviation Administration orders media helicopters to leave the area around Big Bear where authorities search for accused cop killer Christopher Dorner. Law enforcement had expressed concern about helicopters showing officers' movements earlier, asking media not to show their "tactical movements." (L.A. Times)

title: Riverside residents attend vigil for slain officer
caption: Photo: Steven Cuevas/The California Report
body: Riverside police, residents and city officials gathered Thursday evening at Riverside City Hall to mourn the unidentified Riverside police officer allegedly gunned down by ex-LAPD officer Christopher Dorner. About 125 people gathered for the vigil, according to the Press-Enterprise’s Alicia Robinson. Several officers attended with black bands across their badges. (KPCC)

title: 125 law enforcement officers continue search
caption: Photo: Grant Slater/KPCC
body: In a 5:30 p.m. news conference, San Bernardino Sheriff John McMahon says authorities will continue to search the Big Bear area of the San Bernardino Mountains as long as they can, weather permitting. McMahon told reporters that tracks were found near the vehicle and were followed, but they did not lead to the suspect. About 125 law enforcement officers were combing the area around Big Bear Lake for Dorner as a snowstorm approaches, and a three-state manhunt increasingly centered on the rural mountain community, McMahon says, adding that weather won't affect the dogs that are searching for Dorner. (KPCC & KABC)

title: Armed police presence outside LA landmarks
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: Armed police officers stand guard outside the 7th and Metro subway station in Downtown Los Angeles, and tighter security also is evident outside LAPD headquarters. (KPCC)

title: Anderson Cooper reveals Dorner contacted him
caption: Jemal Countess/Getty Images for AWRT
body: About 8 p.m. CNN anchor Anderson Cooper announces via Twitter that his show received a package from Dorner on Feb. 1st, though he was unaware of it. The package contained a note, a DVD and a medal that had been pierced by a bullet. (Twitter)

title: No evidence of Dorner near Big Bear; search continues
caption: Photo: Grant Slater/KPCC
body: As of 9 p.m. a canvass by San Bernardino County sheriff's deputies and other law enforcement officers of more than half of an expected 400 homes in Big Bear hadn't turned up evidence of Dorner's whereabouts. Speaking at a press briefing, San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department spokeswoman Cindy Bachman tells reporters that schools in the Bear Valley Unified School District are expected to be in session Friday morning, and the local ski resort would reopen for business as well. (KPCC)

title: Hoax ties up San Diego officers
body: Between 1:30 and 2:30 a.m., up to 16 San Diego County sheriff's deputies surround a rural home after a hoaxer reported Dorner was there. Investigators have a pretty good idea who made the call and could seek criminal charges. (AP)

title: LAPD cancels tactical alert
body: LAPD officials say they have canceled a tactical alert at about 7:30 a.m., though they "remain vigilant." (KNX1070)

title: Authorities update media on search efforts
caption: Photo: Grant Slater/KPCC
body: During a Friday morning news conference San Bernardino Sheriff John McMahon says there is no evidence that Dorner has come down into the Big Bear community, that a pickup truck belonging to Dorner is being processed in Riverside, that officers plan a multi-agency search of cabins near Big Bear ,and weather conditions prevent the use of helicopters in the search. (KPCC)

title: Former LAPD chief Bill Bratton speaks to KPCC's Alex Cohen and A Martinez
caption: Photo: LAPD
body: Former LAPD Chief Bill Bratton tells TakeTwo's Alex Cohen and A Martinez that he won't speak to whether he is under protection after Dorner mailed CNN his manifesto — which references Bratton — and a ceremonial coin with Bratton's name on it and three bullet holes in it. Bratton goes on to say the LAPD has "most strenuous screening procedures of any police department in the nation," and that after an individual is discharged from the department in the way Dorner was, there would not typically be follow up. (KPCC)

title: Agents complete search of Dorner's Las Vegas home
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: A search of Dorner's Las Vegas home didn't turn up any weapons, the FBI says. FBI Agent Patrick Turner adds that other items found after SWAT teams served a warrant Thursday at the two-story home about nine miles southwest of the Las Vegas Strip will be used to help in the manhunt for Dorner. (AP)

title: Another false alarm in San Diego
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: San Diego authorities search the Westfield Horton Plaza about 10 a.m. after receiving a tip that Dorner was spotted in the vicinity. Previous evidence suggests Dorner had spent parts of Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday in San Diego. KNSD reports: "The man at the focus of the tip had been working out at the gym when an off-duty officer called in the lead, according to one 24 Hour Fitness employee. The misidentified man was in the locker room when he was approached by federal agents and police officers and was “not compliant,” according to Lt. Joseph Ramos." (KNSD)

title: L.A. correctional facility on lockdown
caption: Photo: Christopher Okula/KPCC
body: L.A. County Sheriff’s officials lock down Men’s Central Jail and the Twin Towers Jail in downtown around 8:45 a.m. after an employee thought she saw Dorner entering one of the facilities. “Out of preponderance of caution, the jails and nearby courts were shut down,” Sheriff’s spokesman Steve Whitmore said. Dozens of deputies swarmed the area and searched the massive complex. (KPCC/KCAL-TV/KNX1070)

title: Six officers placed on leave after opening fire on newspaper carriers
caption: Photo: Chris Carlson/AP
body: Six LAPD officers who opened fired on two women in a Toyota Tundra pickup truck similar to Dorner's vehicle are placed on paid administrative leave, a LAPD spokesman says. The officers fired an unknown number of shots at Margie Carranza, 47, and her 71-year-old mother, Emma Hernandez, who were delivering newspapers before dawn. The police officers thought their truck looked like one being driven by Dorner, who earlier that morning had allegedly shot at several officers in Riverside, killing one of them. Carranza required stitches in her hand, and Emma Hernandez was shot twice in her back. Hernandez was in good condition at Harbor UCLA Medical Center. A lawyer for the victims estimates officers fired between 20 and 30 times at the pickup truck. (KPCC)

title: Twin Towers lockdown lifted
body: Shortly before noon, officials lift a lockdown at the Twin Towers Correctional Facility after determining a report of Dorner being in the area was not credible. (KPCC/L.A. Times)

title: Friday update yields no new information
caption: Photo: Chris Carlson/AP
body: Officers continue to search the Big Bear area, and during a news conference just after noon, San Bernardino Sheriff John McMahon says more than 200 Big Bear cabins are abandoned or empty. When asked what it would take to call of the search, McMahon said, "Some reasonable information that would suggest (Dorner is) no longer in this area." Big Bear Lake Mayor Jay Obernolte also spoke at the news conference. He said that the thing he's been asked the most is if people in the community are panicking, and that, no, they're not. "We've been assured that the suspect does not pose a substantial threat to the ski resorts or the surrounding community," Obernolte said. (KPCC)

title: LAPD reinstates its tactical alert
body: KPCC's Erika Aguilar reports that a heavy call load has forced the LAPD to reinstate its tactical alert at about 11:45 a.m. Officials cite numerous calls related to possible sightings of Dorner, in addition to normal service calls. Rudy Lopez from LAPD Media Relations said that LAPD officers don't want to think of Dorner as "one of [their] own." There's no ETA for when the tactical alert will be lifted once again. (KPCC)

title: Officers search home of Dorner's mother
caption: Photo: KPCC
body: KPCC's Molly Peterson and Erika Aguilar report some 12 investigators searched through the home of Dorner's mother on Friday. “They were prepared that he might be here,” Whalen said. Detectives were very cautious when they entered the house, Irvine Police Lt. Bill Whalen says. Whalen wouldn't talk about what evidence was taken from the house or if there were weapons found. The license plates on the cars parked in the garage at the home were removed. News media who had been at the house yesterday say the plates had been removed by the time they got there at 7:30 a.m. Thursday. The Irvine Police Department was the lead agency on the search warrant, assisted by the U.S. Marshals and the regional computer lab, which is overseen by the FBI. There were also detectives from LAPD and the Riverside Police Department there. Officers from the Irvine Police Department, the La Palma Police Department and the U.S. Marshals service — in addition to the Orange County Regional Computer Forensics Laboratory — are at the scene. Officers are seen going in and out of the home in bulletproof vests, Peterson reports. (KPCC)

title: AP details a 2006 court filing after Dorner split with then-girlfriend
body: Court records obtained by The Associated Press show Dorner's ex-girlfriend called him "severely emotionally and mentally disturbed" after the two split in 2006. The court records show Dorner unsuccessfully requested a restraining order against his ex-girlfriend after she posted his badge number on a website called Dontdatehimgirl.com. In the posting, Ariana Williams calls Dorner "twisted" and "super paranoid" and warns other women on the website not to date him. (AP)

title: Naval bases in California and Nevada taking heightened security measures
body: CNN reports that U.S. Naval bases in California and Nevada are "maintaining a heightened security posture," a measure "ordered overnight by Rear Adm. Dixon Smith, commander of the Navy's southwest region." CNN reported the move was made after it became clear that Dorner was able to get access to the Naval Base at Point Loma and stay in a motel there on Tuesday. (CNN)

title: Jackson urges Dorner to surrender to authorities
body: KNX1070′s Charles Feldman reports the Rev. Jesse Jackson issues a public plea to Dorner to surrender to authorities immediately. Jackson, the civil rights icon and leader of the Rainbow PUSH Coalition, said he would gladly receive Dorner himself in order to save lives. (KNX1070)

title: Navy makes Dorner's service record public
body: The U.S. Navy on Friday afternoon releases Dorner's service record and military biographical data. Dorner left the Navy on Feb. 1. (mydesert.com)

title: Beck speaks to the L.A. Times about shooting of newspaper carriers on Thursday
body: The L.A. Times interviews LAPD Chief Charlie Beck, who speaks about the investigation into the shooting on Thursday of 47-year-old Margie Carranza and her 71-year-old mother Emma Hernandez in Torrance. (L.A. Times)

title: Police release wanted poster, image of Dorner taken from security camera
caption: Photo: Irvine Police Department
body: Irvine Police release a wanted poster for Dorner on Friday afternoon containing images taken Jan. 28 from a surveillance camera at an Orange County hotel. Police said they were distributing the photos to give the public the best idea of how Dorner appeared in the recent past, and encouraged anyone with info about his whereabouts to call 911 immediately. (KPCC)

title: Dorner's mother owns land near location of his pickup truck
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: The AP reports that Dorner's mother owns about two acres of land some 35 miles west of where his burned pickup truck was found near Big Bear. San Bernardino County sheriff's spokeswoman Cindy Bachman says authorities are aware of the land and have visited it several times. She says there's been no sign of Dorner in the area.(AP)

title: Neighbor of Dorner's mother says police had been in the area earlier in the week
caption: Photo: KPCC
body: Friday evening, KPCC's Erika Aguilar spoke with a neighbor of Dorner's mother, who says police have been in and out of the neighborhood, keeping an eye on the home since about Tuesday or Wednesday. Dorner came back from Las Vegas and moved back to La Palma for a couple of weeks, the neighbor said. (KPCC)

title: Officer under 24-hour protection speaks with KPCC
body: A 29-year veteran of the LAPD speaks with KPCC's Frank Stoltze about his experience of being under 24-hour protection after he learned of being named in Dorner's manifesto. After he received the call Wednesday night, the veteran officer rushed to round up his family.  One child was at a friend’s house, another in a class. He wants as few details provided about his family and his location as possible.  He is scared. “Dorner said he wants to kill the children of the people on the manifesto,” said the officer, who adds that he appreciates the protection. (KPCC)

title: Dorner's image begins to appear on freeway billboards
caption: Reed Saxon/AP
body: A digital billboard along Santa Monica Boulevard on the west side of Los Angeles is one of several that display "wanted" alerts for Dorner. (KPCC)

title: Search resumes in San Bernardino Mountains
body: More than 100 officers fanned out again at daybreak in the snow-covered San Bernardino Mountains, resuming the search for Dorner. SWAT teams in camouflage scoured the mountains, aware that they could be walking into a trap set by the well-trained former Navy reservist who knows their tactics and strategies as well as they do. (AP)

title: Weapons, gear found in wreckage of Dorner's truck
caption: Photo: Grant Slater/KPCC
body: CBS2 reports authorities found two rifles, a handgun and cold-weather survival gear in Dorner's burned pickup truck found near Big Bear. The broadcast station cites as it source a law enforcement official working on the investigation. Meanwhile, ABC7 reports Dorner's truck had a broken axle, and the two rifles were AR-15 style weapons. (CBS2/ABC7)

title: Land near Big Bear owned by Dorner's mother has been searched
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: Just before 1:30 p.m. NBC4 reports that undeveloped property owned by Dorner's mother has been searched, according to the San Bernardino Sheriff's Department. (NBC4)

title: Authorities search storage locker in Buena Park
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: ABC7 reports Dorner had a storage locker in Buena Park, and authorities searched the facility early Saturday morning. (ABC7)

title: Funeral services scheduled for slain Riverside officer
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: The Press-Enterprise reports that a funeral is scheduled for Wednesday for the Riverside police officer that Dorner is accused of shooting and killing early Thursday. An honor guard will accompany the officer’s casket for its internment at Riverside National Cemetery, according to information on the Riverside Police Department website. Riverside Police Chief Sergio Diaz has asked that the officer’s name not be disclosed to protect his family, The Press-Enterprise reports. (The Press-Enterprise)

title: Team honors Quan during game against UC Riverside
caption: Photo: Corey Moore/KPCC
body: The Cal State Fullerton women's basketball team honors Monica Quan at its afternoon game against UC Riverside at Titan Gym on the Fullerton campus. Quan, who was killed last weekend in Irvine along with her boyfriend, was in her second season as an assistant basketball coach with the Titans. The game is the first for the Titan women's basketball team since Quan's murder. (KPCC)

title: Task force forms, but without San Bernardino County
body: L.A. Weekly reports the L.A. and Irvine Police Departments form a joint task force in the search for Dorner. The task force includes the Riverside Police Department, the FBI and the U.S. Marshals Services. "Noticeably absent from the list is the San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department, which has been searching the Big Bear area for the disgraced former L.A. cop after his truck was found there Thursday morning." (L.A. Weekly)

title: FAA warns of Dorner's ability to fly
body: The Transportation Security Agency cautions airports and pilots that Dorner was believed to have received flight training while in the Navy, "but the extent of his potential flying skills is unknown." (TSA)

title: Protection of LAPD personnel reaches 50 families
body: L.A. Weekly's Dennis Romero reports that 50 families of LAPD personnel have protection details, according to LAPD Chief Charlie Beck. (L.A. Weekly)

title: LAPD chief meets with women mistakenly shot in Torrance by officers
body: LAPD Chief Charlie Beck meets with 47-year-old Margie Carranza and her 71-year-old mother, Emma Hernandez. The two were shot while delivering newspapers before dawn on Feb. 7 after LAPD police officers thought their truck looked like one being driven by Dorner, who earlier that morning had allegedly shot at several officers in Riverside, killing one of them. The AP reports they will get a new pickup truck courtesy of the department. (ABC7/AP)

title: Chief says department will reopen case that led to Dorner's firing
body: LAPD Cmdr. Andrew Smith says the department will reopen the investigation that apparently has led Dorner to seek revenge against former colleagues who he believed cost him his law enforcement career. Police Chief Charlie Beck tells KCBS-TV the department will thoroughly re-examine Dorner's allegation to ensure the public that the LAPD is fair and transparent. He says if Dorner wants to surrender, the LAPD will "be happy to hear what he has to say." (KPCC)

title: Broken axle on truck before fire, or caused by towing for investigation?
body: Police officials in Irvine confirm that Dorner's truck had a broken axle, according to Tami Abdollah from the Associated Press, but can't confirm if it occurred prior to it being set on fire or when authorities towed it from the Big Bear area for analysis. (AP)

title: Evidence recovered from storage locker in Buena Park
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: Irvine police Lt. Julia Engen says evidence was collected late Friday night from a storage locker in Buena Park as part of the Dorner search/investigation. Engen wouldn't elaborate on the nature of the evidence or say who had rented the storage unit. (AP)

title: Report: Man claiming to be Dorner calls father of Monica Quan
body: ABC News reports that a man identifying himself as Dorner called Randall Quan some four days after Monica Quan and her fiance, Keith Lawrence, were found shot to death. On Monday, a federal agent says the phone call was a prank, according to the AP's Tami Abdollah. (ABC)

title: New surveillance video surfaces of man believed to be Dorner
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: Surveillance video released Saturday shows a man believed to be Dorner throwing items into a trash bin behind a National City business on Monday, according to an ABC10 report. "The video, which was obtained exclusively by CNN, was recorded at about 9 a.m. Monday in an alley behind Platinum Auto Sports on National City Boulevard. The video appears to show Dorner pull up in a gray Nissan pickup, get out and begin throwing items into the trash bin." According to the report, an employee found a magazine full of bullets, a military belt and a helmet. (ABC10)

title: LAPD captain taking threat seriously
body: An LAPD captain takes the threat against him seriously, according to an Orange County Register report. Capt. Phil Tingirides, whom Dorner named in his "manifesto," told the newspaper he hasn't been able to leave his home since he learned Christopher Dorner was allegedly seeking revenge against former LAPD colleagues. (O.C. Register)

title: Camping gear also found in Dorner's truck
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: As helicopters equipped with heat-seeking technology resume search for Dorner in the mountains near Big Bear, authorities say camping gear was found, along with weapons, inside his burned truck. LAPD Sgt. Rudy Lopez said Sunday that the truck was so charred that investigators couldn't be more specific about the nature of its contents. (AP)

title: County supervisors offer reward
caption: Erika Aguilar/KPCC
body: Los Angeles County Supervisors Michael D. Antonovich and Mark Ridley-Thomas offer a $100,000 reward for information leading to Dorner's capture. (ABC7)

title: Million-dollar reward offered for Dorner's capture
caption: Photo: Chris Carlson/AP
body: The LAPD and other law enforcement agencies offer a $1 million reward for Dorner's capture. A tip line — (213) 486-6860 — is also established. Los Angeles Mayor Antonio Villaraigosa stresses his support and pride for the work law enforcement agencies have done to date and said it is a matter of time before Dorner is caught. "We will not tolerate this reign of terror," he said. LAPD Chief Charlie Beck said the reward is the largest local reward to date and came together easily with an outpouring support of individual donors, in addition to help from employee agencies statewide. (KPCC)

title: Women mistakenly shot leave the hospital
caption: Photo: Chris Carlson/AP
body: Two women shot and wounded early Thursday by LAPD officers on a protection detail in Torrance are released from the hospital. Margie Carranza, 47, and her mother Emma Hernandez, 71, were delivering newspapers when officers fired as many as 50 bullets at their truck. The officers had been assigned to protect a high-ranking LAPD official who'd been named in the “manifesto” posted online by murder suspect Christopher Dorner. Attorney Glen Jonas, who represents the women, says they tried to cover their heads when the shooting began. He says they prayed they would survive. Hernandez was struck in the back by two shots. (KPCC)

title: Lawyer in second mistaken shooting: "Police were reckless"
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: A lawyer for Dan Perdue says police were reckless when they riddled his client's Honda Ridgeline pickup truck with bullets while guarding the home of a law enforcement official targeted by Dorner. The pickup resembled Dorner's Nissan Titan. After driving away, the Ridgeline was hit by a squad car. Perdue attorney Robert Sheahen tells the Daily Breeze of Torrance that the pickup spun around, and officers began shooting. Perdue wasn't wounded. A police department statement says Perdue's vehicle was suddenly leaving the area, and officers on heightened alert took appropriate measures. (Torrance Daily Breeze)

title: Riverside officer identified
caption: Photo: Riverside Police Department
body: The Riverside Police officer Dorner is accused of killing is identified as 34-year-old Michael Crain. Crain is a former Marine and Redlands native who served two tours in Kuwait and was promoted to sergeant with the 15th Marine Expeditionary Unit, 3rd Battalion 1st Marines. Crain earned multiple honors during his time in the Marines, including a rifle marksmanship badge. He was honorably discharged from the Marine Corps and joined the Riverside Police Department in 2001. Crain served with the Riverside Police Department's SWAT team and also worked as a firearms instructor and a field training officer. (KPCC)

title: Increased security evident at the Grammy's
body: There is a heavier-than-usual police presence at the Grammy Awards as the search for Dorner continues. Police Cmdr. Andy Smith says the always heavily guarded Grammys will see even more officers at Staples Center Sunday. (AP)

title: Northridge responds to Dorner sighting
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: Later determined to have been triggered by a husband and wife dispute, the LAPD and local law enforcement agencies respond to the Northridge area after a report of possible sighting of a man who resembles Dorner near Fashion Mall. News helicopters show police helping customers and employees leave a Lowe's Home Improvement store. (AP/KTLA/KABC/KCBS/KNBC)

title: Tactical alert lifted
body: LAPD lifts tactical alert allowing supervisors to keep officers past their shifts as the search for Dorner enters the fifth day. (AP)

title: Schools re-open in Big Bear
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: Schools in Big Bear open with extra security as police continue to search for Dorner. (L.A. Times)

title: LAPD exploring more than 600 tips
caption: Photo: Chris Carlson/AP
body: Los Angeles Police Chief Charlie Beck Monday said a $1 million reward offer has prompted hundreds of tips on Christopher Dorner, the fugitive ex-LAPD officer who allegedly murdered three people and promised to kill more in revenge for his termination from the department. “We’re getting tips … like crazy,” Beck said. “Hopefully there’s a nugget in there that will lead us to his capture.” They've received approximately 600 tips, Beck said. The chief said detectives are pouring over all of the leads, which are coming in from throughout Southern California. (KPCC)

title: Murder charges filed in connection with officer's death
body: Authorities on Monday file murder charges against Dorner and issue a no-bail arrest warrant. The charges include special circumstances, which would make Dorner eligible for the death penalty if prosecutors decide to pursue it and if he’s convicted. Michael Crain, an 11-year-veteran of the Riverside Police Department, was the training officer allegedly killed by Dorner in an ambush shooting early Thursday. Dorner has also been charged with three counts of attempted murder for shooting at Crain’s partner and two LAPD officers in Corona minutes before ambushing the Riverside officers. Officials are withholding the identities of those three officers because Dorner is still at large. (KPCC)

title: Search continues in Big Bear
body: Authorities in Big Bear Lake continue to search more than 30 square miles day and night for Dorner. San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department spokeswoman Jodi Miller says there are 30 deputies canvassing the Big Bear area and checking on roughly 600 cabins in the manhunt for the 33-year-old fugitive. (AP)

title: Flags at half-staff
body: LA city flags fly at half-staff in honor of slain Riverside Police Officer Michael Crain. Officials say they will remain so until the conclusion of Wednesday's memorial service. (KPCC)

title: Police, others deny drone search for Christopher Dorner, but not all do
caption: Photo: Erika Aguilar/KPCC
body: There's been a buzz around whether unmanned drone aircraft are being used in the search for murder suspect and fugitive ex-LAPD officer Christopher Dorner in the Los Angeles area. The story first surfaced in the British tabloid the Daily Express. KPCC reporters set out to verify or debunk the report. Some police agencies — including the Los Angeles Police Department — flatly denied they were using drones. But others were coy. (KPCC)

title: Increased police presence at border crossings
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: The search for Dorner creates heavy traffic backups at California border crossings into Mexico, as agents are more closely inspecting each car. State police in Mexico's Baja California were given photographs of Dorner and warned to consider him armed and extremely dangerous. Riverside County District Attorney Paul Zellerbach says authorities believe Dorner will emerge at some point and try to continue carrying out his vendetta. "I don't think he's done," Zellerback said. "Just read his manifesto and look at his actions. He's trying to send a message, and it would be my belief that his message is not completed yet." (AP)

title: Document filed last week speculated Dorner fled to Mexico
body: The L.A. Times reports Dorner could have fled to Mexico, based on federal court documents filed on Feb. 7, and may have been helped by an associate identified only as “JY." Meanwhile, the AP's Tami Abdollah reports that authorities no longer believe Dorner fled to Mexico, but at the time of Thursday's filing it was the best lead.(L.A. Times/AP)

title: Police investigate tip on SCUBA purchase
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: Police review tape released by TMZ that supposedly shows Dorner buying scuba equipment at a Sport Chalet store in Torrance days before he is accused of killing two people in Irvine and allegedly going on a shooting spree in the Inland Empire. (KPCC)

title: School closes as precaution
caption: Photo: Brian Watt/KPCC
body: Holy Angels School in Arcadia closes because a relative of the pastor of Holy Angels Parish is named in Dorner’s manifesto. (KPCC)

title: Man thought to be Dorner surfaces
body: 12:20 p.m. San Bernardino County sheriff's spokeswoman Jodi Miller says a stolen vehicle report from a residence was received. "The reporting party identified the suspect as looking like Christopher Dorner, but that has not been confirmed," Miller said. A suspect stole a vehicle described as a white 2008 Dodge pickup and fled the scene. (KPCC)

title: CDFW involved in shootout with man suspected to be Dorner
body: 12:45 p.m. A California Department of Fish and Wildlife officer traveling on Highway 38 recognized a man who fit Dorner’s description in a car traveling in the opposite direction. The wildlife officer pursued the car, and a shooting ensued. The CDFW vehicle was shot numerous times. The suspect escaped on foot. There was an immediate call for backup, which included law enforcement officers from CDFW and other agencies. (CDFW news release)

title: Authorities respond to possible sighting
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: 1:08 p.m. NBCLA reports that authorities are responding to a report of a possible reckless driver and shots fired in Big Bear.

title: Roads closed as chase ensues
caption: Photo: Rina Palta/KPCC
body: 1:16 p.m. Highways 38, 18 and 330 are closed, according to NBCLA.

title: Suspect steals vehicle, ties up couple, attempts to flee
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: 1:39 p.m. The Associated Press reports a law enforcement official says authorities believe Dorner committed a residential burglary of a cabin and had a couple tied up in the cabin along Club View Drive in Big Bear City. One was able to get away and call authorities. The L.A. Times reports authorities believe Dorner broke into a cabin days ago in the San Bernardino Mountains. Then a man believed to be Dorner was spotted by state Fish and Wildlife officers in a white pickup truck, the source said. When they attempted to stop him, Dorner crashed the truck during a chase and exchanged gunfire with the officers as he fled into another cabin, where he was quickly surrounded by San Bernardino County sheriff’s deputies, the source said. (L.A. Times/AP)

title: Police locate vehicle reported as stolen
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: Authorities locate truck reported stolen by suspect authorities believe to be Dorner.

title: FAA issues no fly order near Big Bear
body: 1:44 p.m. Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) issues a three-mile radius, 13,000-foot high temporary flight restriction over Big Bear cabin until futher notice. (FAA)
1:45 p.m. KCAL reports two people shot in apparent shootout with Dorner in Big Bear.

title: Schools on lockdown
caption: Photo: Thomas R. Cordova/Twitter
body: 1:47 p.m. Officials put four Big Bear area schools on lockdown: Baldwin Lane Elementary, Fallsvale Elementary, Chautaqua High School, Mentone Elementary and Big Bear High School. Officials warning parents of students not to go near the schools. (KPCC)
1:49 p.m. The U.S Forest Service reports that none of their personnel has been injured in the shootout. (KPCC)

caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: 1:51 p.m. - Officials respond to Glass Road and 7 Oaks Road, where two officers are reported injured. (ABC7)

caption: Photo: Wendy Lee/KPCC
body: 2:04 p.m. Two injured officers are expected to be airlifted to nearest the trauma center, likely probably Loma Linda. (ABC7)
2:07 p.m. Smoke canisters used during shootout to obscure suspect's visibility so officers could rescue wounded deputy. (KNBC)

title: Lockdowns lifted at three schools; Fallsvale Elem. remains locked down
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: 2:10 p.m. Lockdown lifted for three Big Bear area schools: Baldwin Lane Elementary, Chautaqua High School, Big Bear High School. Fallsvale Elementary remains locked down. (KPCC)

caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: 2:10 p.m. The owner of the cabin where a man thought to be Dorner is hiding says her cabin has lots of windows so the suspect has high visibility of cops.

title: Officers "very close" to cabin when gunfire exchanged
body: 2:20 p.m. San Bernardino County sheriff's spokeswoman Cindy Bachman says officers were "very close" to the cabin when they exchanged gunfire with the suspect, and two officers were hurt.

title: LAPD SWAT team heads toward Big Bear area
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: 2:22 p.m. LAPD SWAT is reported to be en route to Big Bear, where a man suspected to be Dorner is barricaded inside a cabin. (KPCC)

title: LAPD news conference
body: 3 p.m. LAPD Spokesman Andrew Smith says the department stands by ready to assist the San Bernardino Sheriff's Department in the ongoing situation involving suspect thought to be Dorner. (KPCC)

title: Arrowhead Medical Center on alert for victims
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: 3:07 p.m. Arrowhead Medical Center spokesperson tells KPCC's Erika Aguilar the facility is on alert but no officers have arrived. (KPCC)

title: Media asked to stop tweeting
caption: Photo: Screengrab
body: 3:12 p.m. The San Bernardino County's District Attorney's Office tweets that the sheriff's department has asked all members of the press to stop tweeting immediately as it could affect officer safety in the search for Dorner. The tweet making the request has since been deleted.

title: Reports: officer has died as result of injuries suffered in shootout
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: 3:22 p.m. KCAL9's Jeff Nguyen and the L.A. Times reports that one of the San Bernardino Sheriff's deputies dies at Loma Linda Medical Center, following a police shoot out with suspect thought to be Dorner. U.S. Rep. Paul Cook confirms to KPCC's Kitty Felde that one of the injured officers has died.
4:08 p.m. Via Jon Passantino, KCBS reporter Carter Evans at the scene of the barricade situation in San Bernardino mountains says he hasn't heard gun shots in an hour. (CBS)
4:13 p.m. Via Jon Passantino, KCBS reporter Carter Evans reports "green tinted gas" is rising from the cabin Dorner is believed to bne barricaded. (KCBS)

title: Fire begins at cabin
body: 4:13 p.m. Via Jon Passantino, KCBS reporter Carter Evans reports that the cabin where Dorner is thought to be staying is on fire. (KCBS)

title: Sheriff confirms deputy was shot and killed in shoot out
caption: Photo: Mae Ryan/KPCC
body: 4:22 p.m. San Bernardino County Sheriff John McMahon confirms a deputy died at Loma Linda Medical Center following a shoot out earlier in the day with a suspect thought to be Dorner. (KPCC)

title: "Single gunshot heard"
body: 4:38 p.m. Via Jon Passantino, KCBS reporter Carter Evans on the scene, and ABC7 on its news broadcast, report that once the fire began, a single gunshot was heard from within the cabin. (KCBS)

title: Second injured officer expected to survive
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: 4:40 p.m. KPCC's Wendy Lee reports from Loma Linda Medical Center that a second San Bernardino County Sheriff's deputy injured Tuesday in a shootout with the suspect is in surgery and expected to survive. (KPCC)

title: No indication of movement inside
body: 4:47 p.m. The San Bernardino Sun reports the cabin is fully engulfed in flames, with no movement inside. (San Bernardino Sun)

title: Fire continues
body: 4:56 p.m. Via Jon Passantino, KCBS reporter Carter Evans reports the cabin structure is beginning to collapse. (KCBS)

title: Spokeswoman: not confirmed though authorities have reason to believe suspect is Dorner
caption: KPCC
body: 5:16 p.m. San Bernardino County sheriff's spokeswoman Cindy Bachman tells CBS2 on air there hasn't been additional gunfire coming from the cabin since it started on fire. Bachman says authorities have reason to believe the suspect is still inside the cabin and that the individual is Christopher Dorner. "However, we have not absolutely confirmed that," she said. (CBS2)

title: AP: Man inside cabin never emerged
body: 5:27 p.m. The AP's Tami Abdollah reports that the man believed to be Dorner never emerged from the burning cabin. (AP)

title: L.A. Times report details timeline of events at the burning cabin
caption: Photo: Google Static Maps API
body: 5:58 p.m. The L.A. Times reports that police had broken down windows, pumped in tear gas and blasted a loud speaker urging the man suspected of being Dorner to surrender. When they got no response, police deployed a vehicle to rip down the walls of the cabin "one by one, like peeling an onion," a law enforcement official said. By the time they got to the last wall, authorities heard a single gunshot, the source said. Then flames began to spread through the structure, and gunshots, probably set off by the fire, were heard. Dorner's body has not been found. The police search will be focused in the basement area, the source said. (L.A. Times)

caption: Photo: Mae Ryan/KPCC
body: 6:34 p.m. San Bernardino County Sheriff's department confirms to KPCC's Wendy Lee that the body of the deputy who died was transported to coroner's office. (KPCC)

title: Hiding spot's proximity to command post a matter of feet
caption: Photo: Grant Slater/KPCC
body: 7:03 p.m. KPCC visual journalist Grant Slater captured this photo showing the proximity of the cabin where Dorner was reportedly hiding earlier this week and the command center used by authorities. The building on the right was central command for the search; the building on the left is where Dorner reportedly stayed.

title: No confirmation from LAPD
body: 7:14 p.m. KPCC's Erika Aguilar reports that the LAPD says that it hasn't confirmed or made any statements regarding a body being located, removed or identified from the location in San Bernardino County. (KPCC)

title: Paper quotes Riverside police chief as source confirming Dorner's death, statement later retracted
body: 7:32 p.m. The Press-Enterprise quotes Riverside Police Chief Sergio Diaz as saying that Dorner's body was found inside the burnt-down cabin. Less than an hour later, Diaz retracts his statement after Riverside police Assistant Chief Chris Vicino relayed a message to the city council from the chief that Dorner was in the cabin and was dead. (Press-Enterprise)

title: LAPD denies body has been removed from the cabin
body: 8:06 p.m. LAPD Spokesman Andrew Smith disputes multiple reports that surfaced a little more than an hour earlier that authorities found a body in the burned-out remains of the cabin in which a man believed to be Dorner was hiding. Smith tells reporters in downtown L.A. that the "burned cabin has not even been entered by investigators" because it was too hot to be searched, that no body had been removed from the cabin's ruins and that no identification had yet been made. "We are still in a holding pattern ... to see if there's a body in there, and if there's a body in there, to determine if it's Christopher Dorner," Smith said, adding that it might take days or weeks for DNA analysis, dental records identification or other methods that would be able to confirm the identity of any remains located in the cabin. The LAPD was expected to hold another press briefing at 8 a.m. Wednesday. Smith reiterates that the San Bernardino County Sheriff's department investigation has the lead on the investigation and will be conducting follow up. (News conference)

title: San Bernardino County's Bachman says authorities have a huge crime scene to process
body: 8:35 p.m. San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department spokeswoman Cindy Bachman says authorities believe that the suspect who exchanged gunfire with sheriff's deputies and allegedly killed one of them was still inside the cabin as it burned to the ground. Bachman said officers have not entered the cabin and have not confirmed that anything is inside. She says reports earlier that a body was found inside are unconfirmed. Bachman calls the scene of the cabin fire a huge crime scene and anticipates authorities to be there most of the night. She does not know when authorities will enter the remains of the cabin. KPCC's Rima Palta says the San Bernardino County sheriff's confirms the burnt cabin was vacant when the suspect barricaded himself inside. (News conference)

title: Fish and Wildlife's Foy outline events of the afternoon
body: 8:50 p.m. Lt. Patrick Foy of the California Department of Fish and Wildlife says the suspect believed to be Dorner was driving a purple Nissan when he was first seen by wardens, who had to make a U-turn and lost the suspect when he turned onto Glass Road. Foy says the suspect then carjacked a white pickup truck and was again spotted by wardens. At that time the suspect allegedly opened fire and then continued driving until the point where he abandoned the truck. (News conference)

title: San Bernardino County's Sheriff's Department release summarizes days events
body: 8:59 p.m. The San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department issues the following news release: "On Tuesday, February 12, 2013 at 12:22 p.m., deputies working the Big Bear area search for Christopher Dorner responded to the 1200 block of Club View Dr. for a reported stolen vehicle. The reporting party said the suspect took their vehicle and described the suspect as looking very similar to Dorner. Deputies immediately began a search on the ground and from the air for the vehicle. The vehicle was located at Hwy 38 and Glass Rd. The suspect fled into the forest and barricaded himself inside a cabin. A short time later there was an exchange of gunfire between law enforcement and the suspect. Two San Bernardino County Sheriff’s deputies were injured during the gunfire and taken to the Loma Linda Hospital. At approximately 2:24 p.m., one of the deputies was pronounced deceased. The deputy wounded in today’s incident has undergone surgery and medical personnel are optimistic as to his recovery. However, it is believed several additional surgeries will be required. A fire erupted in the cabin in which the suspect had barricaded himself. The cabin remains unsafe for investigators to enter and it is unknown when the structure will be deemed safe. It is believed the suspect is inside the cabin. Homicide investigators have responded and are conducting an investigation. A press conference is scheduled for tomorrow at 4:00 p.m. at sheriff's headquarters located at 655 E. Third Street in San Bernardino. (News release)

title: Sheriff's Department: charred human remains found
body: 11:00 p.m. Investigators locate charred human remains within the debris of the burned out cabin, according to a San Bernardino County Sheriff's Department news release. Identification will be attempted through forensic means, according to the release. The Associated Press reports that a California driver's license with the name Christopher Dorner, and other personal items, have been found in the basement of the burned cabin next to the charred body. (News release)

title: LAPD has news conference to update investigation
body: 8:00 a.m. LAPD Lt. Andy Neiman says a normal state of police operations has resumed but some protective details remain in place. Regarding the effort to identify charred human remains, Neiman says the department doesn't ask for dental records when an individual is hired. (KPCC)

title: Most roads in Big Bear area open to motorists
body: 8:12 a.m. Hwy. 330 and Hwy. 18 open with no restrictions to motorists, according to a news release from the Big Bear Lake Resort Association. Hwy. 38 is open only to residents of Valley of the Falls, Mountain Home Village and Angeles Oaks, the release states. Residents of these communities must show proper identification. Hwy. 38 remains inaccessible to all other traffic until the ongoing investigation is resolved. (News release)

title: Funeral service for slain officer
caption: Photo: Mae Ryan/KPCC
body: 8:12 a.m. Attendees begin to arrive for funeral services for slain Riverside police officer Michael Crain, the 34-year-old veteran training officer who was killed in an ambush shooting early Thursday. A long list of dignitaries is expected to attend the services at the Grove Community Church in Riverside, including Gov. Jerry Brown. The tributes are scheduled to begin early Wednesday when Riverside officers will accompany Crain’s casket from a Magnolia Avenue mortuary to the Grove Community Church, where a funeral will begin at 10:30 a.m. From the church, a procession will take Crain’s body to Riverside National Cemetery for burial in the afternoon. (KPCC)

title: LAPD lifts tactical alert
body: 10:24 a.m. - The Los Angeles Police Department announced Wednesday morning that it was returning to normal operations and had lifted the tactical alert that had been in place frequently during the manhunt for fugitive murder suspect Christopher Dorner. It’s another indication that authorities strongly believe – but cannot definitely confirm – that Dorner died Tuesday in a fire in a cabin near Big Bear. The LAPD announced it was reducing the number of protective details – from about 40 to a dozen. The details had been providing round-the-clock security for the targets identified on Christopher Dorner’s manifesto, and their families. (KPCC)

title: Slain San Bernardino County sheriff's detective identified
body: 12:27 p.m. - The San Bernardino County sheriff's detective killed by Christopher Dorner during Tuesday's firefight in the San Bernardino mountains has been identified by sources as Jeremiah MacKay, a Redlands resident and 1995 Rim of the World graduate. The Inland Empire Emerald Society, where MacKay was a sergeant-at-arms, confirmed the death on their Facebook page. (Daily Bulletin)

title: Slain cop’s wife remembers him at funeral service
body: 1:41 p.m. - Thousands of people gathered Wednesday morning for the funeral of Riverside police officer Michael Crain. He died last week in an ambush. The suspected gunman is former Los Angeles police officer Christopher Dorner. Crain’s wife Regina spoke at the memorial service. She says her husband loved his family time. “When the baby started dancing, I was working and there was a ‘Mommy and Me’ class. It became a ‘Daddy and Me’ class. And I emailed her teacher through all this last few days. And she said it just really stood out in her mind what a loving and devoted father he was to be in a ballet class dancing with this baby.” (KPCC)
